title: Jurić exits Southampton after PL relegation record

summary: Southampton FC announced on Monday that they have dismissed manager Ivan Jurić following the team's relegation from the Premier League. This decision comes as a direct consequence of the club's performance, leading to their drop from England's top football division.

title: Geno Smith grateful to play for Pete Carroll again, says he has 'unfinished business' with Raiders
snippets: Pete Carroll came to Geno Smith's rescue once before, salvaging what was an NFL career seemingly headed nowhere.  Smith's career wasn't at a point where he needed to be rescued again, but his future in Seattle had reached an impasse, creating uncertainty where the 34-year-old quarterback would go next.  Las Vegas turned out to be that place, a chance for Smith to reunite with his former coach as Carroll begins a new stint with the Raiders.
summary: Pete Carroll, previously instrumental in reviving Geno Smith's NFL career, is set to reunite with the 34-year-old quarterback as he begins a new coaching role with the Las Vegas Raiders. This move comes after Smith's future in Seattle reached an uncertain point, signaling a significant shift for both the player and coach. This transition offers Smith a fresh opportunity in Las Vegas under Carroll's guidance.
titles: Geno Smith grateful to play for Pete Carroll again, says he has 'unfinished business' with Raiders

title: Tai 'honored' to be first Singaporean to play in the Masters
snippets: Hiroshi Tai will make history as the first Singaporean golfer to play in the Masters this week, but the 23-year-old can count on a strong Georgia connection to buoy his bid for low amateur honors at Augusta National."So there's a lot of history at Georgia Tech and connected with the Masters.
summary: Hiroshi Tai, a 23-year-old Singaporean golfer, will make history as the first from his country to compete in the Masters. With strong ties to Georgia, where he has connections through Georgia Tech, Tai aims for low amateur honors at Augusta National.
titles: Tai 'honored' to be first Singaporean to play in the Masters

title: Trump Tariff Uncertainty Could Make for a Bumpy Q1 Earnings Season
snippets:
Tariff uncertainty continued to wreak havoc on global markets as businesses and investors braced for tariffs that are expected to lift the U.S. tariff rate to its highest level in more than a century. 

That uncertainty is likely to remain high when S&P 500 companies begin reporting first-quarter results later this week. Wall Street analysts have been increasingly cautious with their outlooks, and some market watchers are forecasting a sharp drop in the number of companies issuing guidance for the current quarter and the remainder of the year. 

The tariff outlook remained murky Monday, with U.S. stocks wavering between gains and losses as Trump threatened to slap an additional 50% tariff on Chinese goods in response to China's retaliatory tariffs. The White House also today quashed rumors that Trump was mulling a 90-day pause on reciprocal tariffs.

The tariffs outlined by Trump last week could scramble global supply chains, raise the risk of a recession, and stoke inflation. In a sign of the times, 421 sell-side broker reports published last week mentioned the word “chaos,” more than twice the prior week’s total, according to AlphaSense. In just the last two days, “chaos” has cropped up in more than 100 such reports.

Companies may choose caution as they report results; ones that have already offered first-quarter guidance have been increasingly wary.

“We will see an upcoming earnings season for 1Q in which it would not surprise us if many companies/mgmt teams did not give guidance,” Wedbush analysts wrote last week. They expect this coming earnings season to resemble early 2020 when uncertainty about the spread of Covid-19 and the longevity of lockdowns caused the number of S&P 500 companies issuing guidance to plummet by more than 50% year-over-year, according to data from FactSet Research.

Market participants are already struggling to make sense of Trump’s tariffs and the impact they could have on their investments. Less guidance would likely reduce investors’ visibility even further, making it more difficult to model earnings growth and, thus, value debt and equity. 

"At a minimum, we will likely see companies give more conservative guidance or wider ranges than normal for guidance," said John Butters, Vice President and Senior Earnings Analyst at FactSet.

White House National Economic Council Director Kevin Hassett on Sunday said more than 50 countries had initiated talks with the administration, seeking relief from the tariffs set to take effect on Wednesday.
summary: Tariff uncertainty is impacting global markets as the U.S. prepares to implement tariffs that could push its tariff rate to the highest in over a century. This uncertainty is expected to affect the upcoming S&P 500 companies' first-quarter earnings reports, with analysts predicting cautious outlooks and a potential decrease in companies issuing guidance. The tariffs, threatened by Trump in response to China's retaliatory measures, risk scrambling global supply chains, increasing recession chances, and stoking inflation. Recent reports show a significant mention of "chaos" in financial analyses
titles: Trump Tariff Uncertainty Could Make for a Bumpy Q1 Earnings Season

title: Apple Plans To Ship More iPhones From India Amid Steep China Tariffs, Report Says
snippets:
Key Takeaways

  • Apple intends to send more iPhones to the U.S. from India in response to high tariffs on goods from China, according to a Wall Street Journal report Monday.
  • The measure is thought to be temporary while the company tries to win a tariff exemption from the Trump administration.
  • Apple shares have lost about a fifth of their value since the Trump administration announced sweeping new tariffs last Wednesday.


Apple (AAPL) plans to send more iPhones to the U.S. from India in response to the Trump administration’s steep tariffs on goods from China, according to a Wall Street Journal report Monday.

The move is reportedly considered a short-term measure as Apple works to secure an exemption from the tariffs, like the one it received from the tariffs President Trump imposed during his first administration. 

Apple did not immediately respond to a request for comment. 

Trump announced a 34% tariff on goods from China last week, on top of a 20% import tax imposed earlier in the year. Tariffs on Chinese goods could also rise further, Trump warned Monday, if the administration responds to China’s decision Friday to institute a 34% tariff on U.S. goods with a higher rate. Trump had announced a 26% tariff on goods from India, by comparison. 

Apple manufactures 90% of its hardware in China, and the company would need to raise prices 6% in order to offset the impact of tariffs if it isn't granted an exemption, JPMorgan analysts said last week. Potentially helping Apple's case is an announcement in February that it plans to invest more than $500 billion in the U.S. over the next four years, the analysts said.

Shares of the iPhone maker dropped close to 4% in Monday's session and have lost about a fifth of their value since the tariffs were announced last Wednesday through Monday’s close.
summary: Apple is increasing iPhone shipments from India to the U.S. as a short-term response to avoid high tariffs on Chinese goods imposed by the Trump administration. The company is seeking a tariff exemption, similar to one it previously received. This move comes after Apple's shares fell by approximately 20% following the announcement of new tariffs. Apple, which produces 90% of its hardware in China, might have to raise prices by 6% without an exemption. The company announced plans to invest over $500 billion in the U.S. over the next four years, potentially supporting its case for an exemption.
titles: Apple Plans To Ship More iPhones From India Amid Steep China Tariffs, Report Says

This declaration underlines the EU's approach to diplomacy and negotiations, focusing on principles other than direct retaliation.
titles: EU drops bourbon, wine and dairy products from tariffs list against US

title: No, the dire wolf has not been brought back from extinction
snippets: Colossal Biosciences claims three pups born recently are dire wolves, but they are actually grey wolves with genetic edits intended to make them resemble the lost species
summary: Colossal Biosciences recently announced the birth of three pups, claiming they are dire wolves. However, these animals are genetically edited grey wolves, modified to mimic the extinct species' characteristics. This revelation clarifies the true nature of the pups as part of the company's efforts to recreate the appearance of dire wolves through genetic engineering.
titles: No, the dire wolf has not been brought back from extinction

title: DOGE ditching tape storage could put data at risk, say experts

summary: President Trump's DOGE team, led by Elon Musk, announced a $1 million saving by replacing 70-year-old tape data storage. However, experts warn this decision may result in higher long-term costs and potential data security risks.
titles: DOGE ditching tape storage could put data at risk, say experts

The creators assert that this drone offers a safer alternative for marine exploration compared to traditional methods.
titles: Bacteria-inspired robot uses 12 spinning flagella to roam underwater
